articles.headline: Sam Bankman-Fried Testifies That He Made ‘Larger Mistakes’ at FTX
articles.snippet: Speaking in his own defense at his criminal trial, the FTX founder denied he had committed fraud but acknowledged missteps that hurt the cryptocurrency exchange’s customers.
articles.abstract: Speaking in his own defense at his criminal trial, the FTX founder denied he had committed fraud but acknowledged missteps that hurt the cryptocurrency exchange’s customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the Sam Bankman-Fried fraud trial.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany, Matthew Goldstein and J. Edward Moreno

articles.headline: U.S. Airstrikes Contain Twin Messages to Iran, American Officials Say
articles.snippet: The airstrikes were the latest gamble by the United States to modify Iran’s behavior, few of which have worked in the past.
articles.abstract: The airstrikes were the latest gamble by the United States to modify Iran’s behavior, few of which have worked in the past.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American strikes on two Iranian military munitions stockpiles in Syria on Friday were carefully designed, President Biden’s aides said, to send two distinct messages to Tehran.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: Israel Intensifies Gaza Strikes and Says It Is Expanding Ground Activity
articles.snippet: Cellular and internet service abruptly vanished for much of the territory, stoking fears that a full-scale invasion was imminent — or already underway.
articles.abstract: Cellular and internet service abruptly vanished for much of the territory, stoking fears that a full-scale invasion was imminent — or already underway.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Israeli military launched a particularly intense bombardment of the Gaza Strip late on Friday and said it was “expanding ground activity” there overnight, while cellular and internet service abruptly vanished for much of the territory, raising the possibility that a full-scale invasion was underway or imminent.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley, Ronen Bergman, Karen Zraick and Hiba Yazbek

articles.headline: For Mike Johnson, Religion Is at the Forefront of Politics and Policy
articles.snippet: The new House speaker has put his faith at the center of his political career, and aligned himself with a newer cohort of conservative Christianity that some describe as Christian nationalism.
articles.abstract: The new House speaker has put his faith at the center of his political career, and aligned himself with a newer cohort of conservative Christianity that some describe as Christian nationalism.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the moments before he was to face a vote on becoming speaker of the House this week, Representative Mike Johnson posted a photograph on social media of the inscription carved into marble atop the chamber’s rostrum: “In God We Trust.”
articles.byline: By Annie Karni, Ruth Graham and Steve Eder

articles.headline: Suspect in Maine Shooting Is Found Dead, Ending Sprawling Manhunt
articles.snippet: The body of the man suspected of killing 18 and injuring 13 others in Lewiston was found with an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound late Friday.
articles.abstract: The body of the man suspected of killing 18 and injuring 13 others in Lewiston was found with an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound late Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: The man suspected of killing 18 people and injuring 13 others at a bar and a bowling alley in Lewiston, Maine, on Wednesday night was found dead of an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound on Friday, officials said, ending a sweeping manhunt that had forced thousands of residents throughout the region to remain in their homes.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Jenna Russell and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: Writing ‘Maid’ Pulled Stephanie Land Out of Poverty. She’s Fine Now, Right?
articles.snippet: Despite writing a best seller that became a hit Netflix series, Ms. Land says she still worries about her job security.
articles.abstract: Despite writing a best seller that became a hit Netflix series, Ms. Land says she still worries about her job security.
articles.lead_paragraph: What do you do with the money you earn from a story you wrote about not having much for too many years?

articles.headline: Gaza’s Tunnels Loom Large for Israel’s Ground Forces
articles.snippet: Hamas is believed to hide weapons, fighters and even command centers in miles of subterranean pathways and chambers.
articles.abstract: Hamas is believed to hide weapons, fighters and even command centers in miles of subterranean pathways and chambers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just after midnight on Tuesday, the Israel Defense Forces announced that they had struck a tunnel that allowed Hamas to “infiltrate Israel through the sea.”
articles.byline: By Adam Goldman, Helene Cooper and Justin Scheck

articles.headline: Israel-Hamas War Enters ‘Second Stage,’ Netanyahu Says
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel did not describe the ground incursion as an invasion, but it was accompanied by an enormous aerial and artillery bombardment.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel did not describe the ground incursion as an invasion, but it was accompanied by an enormous aerial and artillery bombardment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said in a televised news conference on Saturday that Israel’s forces had entered the Gaza Strip, calling it his country’s “second war of independence” and warning Israelis to expect a “long and difficult” campaign to eradicate Hamas.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley, Ronen Bergman and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: Tug-of-War Over N.B.A. Rights Provides Glimpse of Media’s Future
articles.snippet: The league’s longtime television partners, including ESPN and Turner, are undergoing major changes, which could alter how games are watched.
articles.abstract: The league’s longtime television partners, including ESPN and Turner, are undergoing major changes, which could alter how games are watched.
articles.lead_paragraph: The National Basketball Association’s season tipped off on Tuesday with stars like LeBron James and Nikola Jokic beginning the long quest for a title. But the action that will have longer-term ramifications for the league, and the media and entertainment landscape, is happening off the court.
articles.byline: By Kevin Draper and Benjamin Mullin

articles.headline: Friends From Childhood. Brothers in War.
articles.snippet: Three friends met as boys in western Ukraine. When Russia invaded, they enlisted in the same unit. There was comfort, and dread, in serving together.
articles.abstract: Three friends met as boys in western Ukraine. When Russia invaded, they enlisted in the same unit. There was comfort, and dread, in serving together.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a gas station in western Ukraine, three men in their late 20s, friends since childhood, slid into plastic chairs. Exhausted and anxious, they began to sing.

articles.headline: Reaction to Hamas Attack Leaves Some Jews in Hollywood Feeling Unmoored
articles.snippet: The response to the Oct. 7 assault, and to Israel’s retaliation, has revealed a schism in the entertainment world that many did not realize was there.
articles.abstract: The response to the Oct. 7 assault, and to Israel’s retaliation, has revealed a schism in the entertainment world that many did not realize was there.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the exception of the rare conservative, Hollywood has long seemed to exist in an ideological bubble — a bastion of progressive politics, where Jewish people have thrived, Democratic politicians have been celebrated and stars have espoused liberal ideas from the Oscar stage and rushed to support movements like Black Lives Matter.
articles.byline: By Nicole Sperling and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Halloween Shoppers Not Spooked as Economic Slowdown Remains Elusive
articles.snippet: From apple picking to skeleton cows, early seasonal spending seems solid. It’s the latest sign that Federal Reserve policy to combat inflation hasn’t slowed growth.
articles.abstract: From apple picking to skeleton cows, early seasonal spending seems solid. It’s the latest sign that Federal Reserve policy to combat inflation hasn’t slowed growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: Economists spent much of 2023 warning that a recession could be imminent as the Federal Reserve raised interest rates to the highest level in more than two decades. But for companies like Soergel Orchards in western Pennsylvania, a slowdown is nowhere in sight.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Jordyn Holman

articles.headline: 34 Hours of Fear: The Blackout That Cut Gaza Off From the World
articles.snippet: As Israeli forces entered Gaza on Friday to fight Hamas, phone and internet service was severed, sowing chaos for Palestinian civilians and leaving rescuers driving blindly toward explosions.
articles.abstract: As Israeli forces entered Gaza on Friday to fight Hamas, phone and internet service was severed, sowing chaos for Palestinian civilians and leaving rescuers driving blindly toward explosions.
articles.lead_paragraph: For 34 hours, the vast majority of the more than two million Palestinians who live in Gaza had no way to reach the outside world, or one another.
articles.byline: By Abu Bakr Bashir, Iyad Abuheweila, Vivian Nereim and Yousur Al-Hlou

articles.headline: How Years of Israeli Failures on Hamas Led to a Devastating Attack
articles.snippet: Israeli officials completely underestimated the magnitude of the Oct. 7 attacks by Hamas, shattering the country’s once invincible sense of security.
articles.abstract: Israeli officials completely underestimated the magnitude of the Oct. 7 attacks by Hamas, shattering the country’s once invincible sense of security.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our latest updates on the Israel-Hamas war.
articles.byline: By Ronen Bergman, Mark Mazzetti and Maria Abi-Habib

articles.headline: Seeking the ‘Right’ Customers, an Insurer Is Accused of Discrimination
articles.snippet: Erie Insurance defends its practice of telling agents to use subjective factors when judging a potential customer. Maryland regulators say the company sought to exclude Black and Hispanic people.
articles.abstract: Erie Insurance defends its practice of telling agents to use subjective factors when judging a potential customer. Maryland regulators say the company sought to exclude Black and Hispanic people.
articles.lead_paragraph: When regulators in Maryland said this spring that the small company Erie Insurance had illegally avoided selling policies to people in mostly Black neighborhoods, Erie had a ready answer: It said it was being singled out for simply doing business as usual.

articles.headline: Autoworkers Score Big Wins in New Contracts With Carmakers
articles.snippet: Tentative accords at Ford Motor, General Motors and Stellantis are the most generous in decades, raising costs as the industry shifts to electric vehicles.
articles.abstract: Tentative accords at Ford Motor, General Motors and Stellantis are the most generous in decades, raising costs as the industry shifts to electric vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: A six-week wave of strikes that hobbled the three largest U.S. automakers has resulted in tentative contract agreements that would give workers their biggest pay raises in decades while avoiding a protracted work stoppage that could have damaged the economy.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Neal E. Boudette
